So your cousin Tridewell may lawfully pursue his hopes in your bride, whom he loves as eagerly as the melancholy virgin dotes on you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But may this hold good in law captain?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: There's a ganon for it sir. If both parties agree to a divorce after marriage, so it be before copulation.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Though the former part of his discourse, was a most egregious lie, yet the last hath some sound of pleasure in it: which I may make use of.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Come gi'me the instrument. Shall I never find thee anywhere , but thou wilt by just desert exact a beating from me? Hast thou no conscience? wouldst thou have me lame myself, or melt my grease upon thee. Come sir, I have overheard you all; give me the instrument, the instrument I say. Indeed I'll have it. So. Now sir —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay cousin, for the service he hath done you tonight , and love of me, pardon him this time. Besides, his charge is in the house, at whose charge he lives. You will both shame and undo him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Well sir, I shall for this time pardon you, and never beat you more, it before sir Philip here you will subscribe to this. 'tis nothing but a faithful protestation to do reasonable things as I shall appoint, and not to reveal what I shall trust you withal.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: If you will covenant on your part in defence of my reputation, to let me rail at you behind your back, I will subscribe ▪

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Take your pleasure. I am content. Write sir.
In what without a knave we cannot end,
A knave employed does th' office of a friend.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Here sir, I deliver it as my deed.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Here, and I deliver you this again to keep. Indeed you shall for performance of covenants.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O sir you are defeated. My sister hath fortified her lodging with locks, bolts, bars, and barricadoes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To what end brother: for what cause?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I know not whither it be discontent or wilfulness, that possesses her: but you are to have no entrance there tonight . That she has sufficiently sworn.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How! am I denied? To my wish.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: Pray let me speak with you sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: At large you shall. For though it be my wedding night you shall be my bedfellow. Lights there. Good night brother.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Good night captain.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now governor? what has angered thee? something troubles thy countenance.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Your coming, and the privilege of this place hath once more preserved that unworthy Tridewell from the justice of my fury, which should have fallen on him, had he been twinned with me by this light.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By this light, governor? would you have fought by candle-light.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir I dare do't by day light, moonlight, starlight.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ow'e-light.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Any light under the sun. And that shall be tried well on Tridewell head, dec hear?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A good jest! Tried well upon Tridewell. He has wit in his anger. But governor, laying your anger aside, let me be beholden to your wit in achieving this Northern lass. Thy acquaintance with her must be the means. Prithee go lie with me, and help me to dream out some course. Nay look now thy fury blows so high thou dost not hear me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Not h●are? yet, were I in a combat as great as ever I myself fought any, I could both hear, and give counsel. Therefore say unto yourself, by the help of your
governor she is your own.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O man passed example!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: But d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Here, here. Thou shalt have anything —

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Come your way's housewife. No more of your whynings, and counterfet tricks. If this gentleman be not worthy of your love, I am not worthy to be your uncle, directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Alas, what mean you sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Accept of him, you accept of me. if you refuse him you deny me directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: She understands you not a word sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: If you will join hands and faith with him, here's your portion, there's your jointure; if not, your way lies before you, pack directly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Good sir, consider her disease. If her understanding were direct, you might speak directly to her. But if I have any discretion she is too full of melancholy to be purged this way.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: What would you have me do? Or how in your discretion would you council me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Not to be mad sir, because she is melancholy, not by taking a wrong course for her recovery to ruin her, and forfeit your judgement do you think, that commands with chidings, threats, or stripes have power to work upon her, when she has neither will nor reason within herself to do, or not to do anything whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now the gigs up.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: If her health in sense and understanding were perfect: yet as she is woman, her will were first to be wrought upon by fair and gentle treaty. But as she is at this time so sick in mind, that knowledge of what she is, what she do●, especially of what she should do is dead in her, her mind must be first recovered; and that by a due course, in soft and temperate proceedings; to which fit time as well as means must be allowed. Moreover —

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Oh. No moreovers I beseech you, not more of her at this time. I understand your purpose already. I do directly. Therefore speedily take what course, and use what means shall in your discretion be thought fit. I will subscribe, I will directly subscribe to your discretion. My wife when she went out of the world left me as great a care behind her in the charge she gave me with this woman, this quick sighted guide of my house, a blind one were better.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You should first see, if it pleased you, how her affection may be wrought upon by the gentleman's own fair entreaty. Pray sir speak to her like a su●er, look upon him sweet heart: this gentleman loves you. Pray speak sir. Do you not?

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: Never credit me pretty gentlewoman —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nor will I, fear it not. Nor any man that says he loves me. For alas! I was too lately scorned.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: You are a l●sse indeed. I protest and vow, and such ●●ne, as I would be very sorry to appear any way, or in the least decree, as it were please you to understand me: for I'll be sworn, ●he●e is not in the world.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Truth in swearing, less in promising.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: If you will believe me lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nor ne man for your sake.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: There is not in the world I say —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I say so too sir. What wast I pray.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: There is not in the world any gentlewoman —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Tell that no further; for we are all too gentle lessen men were less cruel.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Hear him speak Constance.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You shall hear me sing first by your leave.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Poor heart.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Here's wise work! direct lunacy and idiotism. Bless my house from the ward masters informers,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Pray sir, are you sir Philip?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Say you are.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: Yes lady, I am sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: But you are none of my sparrow. Your mouth's not wide enough for your words.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: She has stopped his mouth there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: His words would soften adamantine ears. And looks would melt a marble heart to tears. O uvea is me!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Nay you must not weep sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: What 〈◊〉 I do them? Shall I ever get him by singing trou ye? Introth I would never but sing, if I thought that were the gainest way.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I had rather hear you sing though, then see you weep.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: It must be of my love than, my sparrow as I told you. And thus it goes.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: A bonny bonny bird I had
A bird that was my marrow:
A bird whose pastime made me glad,
And Philip 'twas my sparrow.
A pretty playfere: chirp it would,
And hop, and fly to fist,
Keepe cut, as ● were a usurer's gold,
And bill me when I list.
Philip, Philip, Philip it cries
But he is fled and my loy dies.
But were my Philip com'd a gain,
I would not change my love
For Juno's bird with gawdy train,
Nor yet for Venus' dove.
Nay, would my Philip come again,
I would not change my state,
For his great name sakes wealth of Spain,
To be another's mate.
Philip Philip, etc.

sp.p: No no, you cannot be the man. I know him right we'll by you sir, as wily as you be. Gin you had all his trim gear upon you, and all his sweets about you, yet I should not be so fond to mistake a Jenny how let for a tassel gentle. Ah, ah, ha.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Why Lone, what fault do you find in this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Faith, but e'en eane. That her is not sir Philip. For thus would he do. Thus would he kiss his hand; and thus ta'me by mine. Thus would he look, and set his eye on mine: and give me leave to see myself in's eyes. 'twas the
best glass introth that ere I saw. I ne'er look we'll fine. Nor ere shall I'm sure, until I see me there again.
sp.l: But he is geaue, alas he's geane, and all too late I sorrow.
For I shall never be well again, till yesterday be to marrow.
sp.p: God you good even sir. —

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: ●ollow her sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And put her to't sir, and out of this humor. I'll add the tother five hundred to her portion, and you bring her about handsomely. O when I was a bachelor! I think I can do somewhat yet in my old days. But when I was a bachelor, how I could have handled this gear.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: Never credit me sir, if you will believe me but —

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I do believe you sir sufficiently good master nonsense. No more of your impertinent speeches. But follow her, and put her to't I say, to't directly. Take her into the orchard 'twas there she fell in love they say it may be the place is o neno ●.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, there will be no way for her recovery, but to remove. her lodging, and have some good physicians about her.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Where you please; and use whose help you please: she is your own; dispose of her freely, as I will of what is 〈…〉 course of life directly. Let me see. She is lost, passed recovery. Say I should marry, I might yet have an 〈…〉 mine own.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes, but of whose getting sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: There might rise a fearful question.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Think not of it sir. A man of your years, and gravity, with the respect the world gives you for your place and worship in the common wealth, together with the riches you have p●ld up in a mountainous estate; to cast all down with yourself , and fortune at the foot of a stranger I think what would be thought of you, if such a dotage should possess you

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: She's falling into a tedious lecture.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Pray how was master Spartledirt talked on tother day for doing such a trick? yet he was held a wise lawyer: you see a fair example in the late marriage of sir Philip luckless, and his Fitchow, a match of your own making, and cause of your nieces and your owne misfortune.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: No more I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: There's tugging for a mastery, and buffetting for the breeches. He barks at her, she snaps at him; she breaks his wine glass, he her looking glass; she puts away his servants, he turns away hers; she locks her chamber door, he bolts his, begetting nothing but a world of strife and disorder.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I pray shut up that point, I will not marry. No directly I will not, though the truth is my purpose: was to have cast myself and fortune wholly upon you, if it might have seemed well in your discretion, umh umh.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I pray stay a little sir, take me along with you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Not a step further, this way by your leave. I think I have puzzled her discretion.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Understand me sir. As I would not have you fall rashly upon anything; no more would I have you fly suddenly from any purpose, without advise and sober deliberation. If you should marry one that would be a comfortable nurse unto you, as (Though I say't) you partly know —

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Say you nothing, ●er I do know nothing, nor I will know nothing more of this matter directly: for if ever I marry, let me suffer all that the-law provides for perjury; let me be cropped and slit worse than a French Curtall, or a parliamental delinquent for blaspheming the blood royal. No, I wil now bestow my wealth in monumental good deeds, and charitable uses in my life time, to be talked well on when I am dead.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes, build alms houses and hospitals for beggars, and provide in Bridewell, and houses of correction for your friends and kindred. Pray give enough to bedlam, you may feel some part of that benefit yourself before you die, if these sits hold you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: She would have me do no good with that I have neither. Let me consider. The most I have to say directly hath not been very well gotten. Were it not a point of good conscience, to spend that prodigally, and save a 〈…〉 and that which I have got well and honestly, hath been with much care and travel; were it not then a point of equity to myself, to spend that with ease and pleasure? 'tis done directly, what I have is mine own; and I will be merry with it. Within there ho.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: What's the toy now?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sirrah. Take there twenty pieces. B stow it all presently in choicest meats, and richest wines for my supper. This one nights supper directly. What I have is mine own: and I will be merry with it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Cl●. Bless us!

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Six brace of partridges, and six pheasants in a dish. Godwits, knots, quails, and the rest of the meres answerable for half a score, or a dozen persons of the best quality: whom I will think of presently.

sp.speaker: Cl●.
sp.p: Brain of a down right justice! What means my master, to leap out of thirty shillings a week house keeping into twenty pounds a supper? I may sell my clerks place: for sure he means to thrust himself out of the commission. He can be no justice long if this humour hold. Who shall be the guests tro●?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I have it directly. You shall go to the ordinaries, and from thence invite such young gallants as you find to be gamesters. I mean of the highest cut.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Men that you do not know sir?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I directly. If they know me, or have heard of me 'tis sufficient: we shall be soon acquainted. Bring not a man with any paid for gold lase or scarlet about him, I charge you, nor without a protection in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You run a great hazard in this sir. You may perhaps be cheated of all you have, if I have any discreation.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And much good do't their good hearts. What I have is mine own, and I will be merry with it directly. You have put me by one or two courses: but not all your discretion shall beat me out of this. If you take some care in the business, and housewife the entertainment to make it brave for my credit, you may get a gown or a jewel by it. If not —

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir I'll obey you. If he be mad I will not be foolish, bat strike in for a ●●are. And for your guests sir, let me alone. My man is best acquainted at the ordinaries.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Why now you speak.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Within there. Beavis. But introth sir, I doubt whether any such guests will come, you have always been so strict and terrible in your justiciary courses.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Let him say mine eyes are opened, and their virtue is revealed
unto me. And if any of the youngsters have mistresses, let 'em bring 'em. They shall have Mn●cke● what I have is mine own, and I will be merry with it. My flesh, though not in the way of marriage, requires some satisfaction too. Where might a man in all this plentiful town, find a choice piece directly that he might make his own? only his own? A very hard question. And custom has made it almost an unreasonable, though it were in ones own wife. In a citizen's or tradesman's wife; a man must suffer the rivalship of a slovenly husband: the stink of his horns ever under ones nose. A cast lady, or gentlewoman of courtly acquaintance, to maintain her, is to feed a fountain, that wastes itself through many spouts: what I supply her with, will be drawn out by twenty. All her friends must share of my prodigality. To train up an innocent country girl, is like hatching a cuckoo; as soon as she is ripe, and sees the world afore her, she flies at her advantage, and leaves me dead i'the nest. How now.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sir, here's a delinquent brought before your worship to be examined, a gentlewoman sir.

sp.speaker: Sq●.
sp.p: Who brings her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ve●hem the constable sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Look on his feet. Sure 'tis the devil in his likeness: that old bawd knowing how it stood with me, has brought me one of his succubae art. Sure 'tis Vexhem?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sure sir? The devil himself knows him not better than I know him from the devil. I am sure, he has been in see with me these nine years: almost ever since he was constable; and has brought more profit to my desk then all the honest officers in the counties of your commission sir. O he's a rare fellow, he'll tickle a whore in coany.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: You know my mind. I will in and handle this g●ere in privity.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Beavis, you understand me. Prithee go discreetly about it.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Pray let me see a little of this first.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: If I put her to't or ever offer to put any woman to't again, never credit me: let me never be trusted, I protest and 〈◊〉 gentlewoman she has used me —

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Very ill favouredly methinks .

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Have you put her to't sir.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: I cannot put her to't, nor she will not be put to't. Sing.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I won't go to't, nor I man not go to't,
For love, nor yet for see:
For I am a maid, and will be a maid,
And a good one till I die.
Yet mine intent, I could repent, for ●ne mane company.
sp.p: But you are not he sir. If you be, you are wondrously changed. I am sure his faults were not written on his forehead. God pardon him.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: If mine be, you can best read 'em, 'tis your own hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: She has done a cure on him. He spoke sense now. Alas sir, that a fair hand should make such blots I what hand is it? Secretary, Roman, court, or text? I have not seen the like: 'tis all dominical letters, red ink. His face is like an almanac of all holy days.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sure 'tis stenography, every character a word: and here and there one for a whole sentence.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Here's one might serve for a whole history. The life and death o' 'Raw head, and bloody bones.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: I see I am not such an ass, I would I might never stir but I am — where's sir Paul if I do not tell him —

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: What did you to provoke her thus?

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: Nothing but what I can answer in a sort d'ye see me as well as — never gi'me credit I had warrant under his hand

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: N●●.
sp.p: By word of mouth sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: That's about hand by your leave.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Is it so? Good sir, his meaning was, you should put her fairly on like a lover, with sweet speeches, and gentle behaviour.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: She understands nothing that I can speak.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Nor anybody else I think.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: And therefore you fell to express yourself in rude action. She has scorned you but well: you are a fine butter to't indeed.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Mum to●t mun toot, muntara rara muntara ra ra rarie,
and ever I sigh and cry alack for Phillip's love I die.

Just so did our dairy maid at home serve my lady Fiddledee's batler. And there I learned it. But when she had so done what did she then do? Bestowed a pennyworth of unguentum album, and it made him whole presently. Good mrs. Trainwell send to your apothecary for some: 'twill make him we ● enough now.

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.p: I sweetheart: but first you shall go in the coach with●● to the doctors.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.p: I know I am not we'll too. But I'll ha' no doctor but sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: It shall be sir Philip, (Poor soul,) all must be sir Philip. You shall lie at his house.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: But not with him by my faith, and your leave, in't we be married. Prithee Beavis gar him wash his face he'll scare somebody's barns else. —

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I'll throw him into the dock rather than he shall succeed Jack O'dandy. Come sir, all shall be well again. Fear not.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: I thank you sir.

div.head: Act. iii. Sce. iii.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Cousin, I understand you at full. And am glad that occasion hath pointed out a probability to lead me out of this labyrinth; and you to your desired end.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Follow but the way you are in sir, and you shall arrive at your own wishes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She has put me into't herself too.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: By sequestering herself from you the first night.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: For which cousin, if I take not occasion to keep myself from her, all nights, days, and times hereafter, may the act of our bodies beget prodigious monsters and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: A fearful vow! look to't. And I warrant she sues for the divorce first.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
May we prove but as certain as you are confident in out other project, for recalling Constance to herself, and me
then to her, these ●etters being shaken off, may they prove golden ones to you, I shall not envy you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: For her take no thought sir. The interest I have in her tutress, with the work I have fashioned upon my anvil, shall bring all to your wish. I expect to hear from him instantly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'll freely resign your wish to you, and add half I have to augment her estate to you. O I tremble to think on her: her presence shakes the house like an earthquake: the outrage of prentices is not so terrible to a bawd or a cutpurse, as her voice is to me. Yet to you she may be calm as the breath of friendship, and mild as the midnight whispers of chaste love.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sir, I profess my affection flies eagerly at her. She takes me deeply, however you have mistaken one another. O here comes my anvil! Methinks his very countenance invites me to strike him ▪ though I know he dos me good service now.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: 'Tis done sir. I warrant she's placed, successfully, d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: How prithee?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I have sent her before his worship by a constable.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who has he sent? before whose worship?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You shall know all. He has sent your cast whore before sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The mystery, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: The success shall unfold it in good time to your and my benefit? doubt not, if she but follow her instructions.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, if she be not mistress of her art, there is no deceit among trade's men, no bribery among officers, no bankrupt out of Ludgate, nor whore out of Bridewell.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And if I ha' not fitted her with a second, my friend vex him, the constable, then say there is no wit among knaves, no want among scholars, no rest in the grave, nor unquietness in marriage, d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Of which here comes the truest testimony.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Out of my doors thou miscreant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay sister. O governor, art here.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p:
Avoid my house, and that presently, I'll claw your skin
off after your livery else, and make you so much nakeder than time makes all other serving creatures.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do you talk of turning away my man? You shall give me leave to turn away your howdee first, and then put off my, God a mercy how dost thou.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Am I jeered? flouted to my face? Is this fit usage for a wife?

sp.speaker: Lu●.
sp.p: A wife? A witch.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: A husband? A hangman.

sp.speaker: Lu●.
sp.p: Out puss.

sp.speaker: Trid.
sp.p: Nay sir, indeed the fault is yours most extremely now. Pray sir forbear to strain beyond a woman's patience.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Am I scorned and reviled?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Made a property for laughter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Have I no friend, no servant to command?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Has my ladyship made me so lamentable a thing, that I have lost the power of a mistress? You sir, run and call some friends to succour me, or I'll throttle you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Stir but a foot sirrah, or utter but a syllable, and I'll cut your throttle pipe.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I shall be carved out betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: What will become of me? you, woodcock, ninihammer.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Have you forgotten my name sister? would not Widgin● become your mouth, as well? forget your natural brother's name?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Can you call me sister, and see me abused thus?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Foutre for sisters; I am not to meddle with another man's wife. I am about one for myself. You mentioned her first to me. But I must be be holden to others wits and means to compass her: or else —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do as I bid you, or —

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O sir she'll rend me in pieces, tear me like a lark.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Dost thou fear her or me. Do't or I —

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir, there's master Walter can sing it rarely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So he shall sir, and so will all; but you must put us in. Begin.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Hey down down, etc.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister, wife, and all, is a present nothing to this. Come round gentlemen ▪ keep her but off, and let me alone.

div.p: They all take hands, and dance round. Widgeon in the midst sings this song. They all bear the burden, while she scolds and strives to be amongst 'em. Tridewell holds her off.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: He that marries a scold, a scold,
He has most cause to be merry:
For when she's in her fits, he may cherish his wits
By singing hey down derry.

sp.speaker: A●l.
sp.p: — Hey down down derry down down down, etc.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I cry you mercy gallants. I apprehend you would be private.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O no master Bulfinch, you shall make one of our council.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: I apprehend gentlemen you are merrily disposed; in good sadness.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Apprehend a fool's head. Come into play.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, 〈◊〉 with him, and about again.

div.stage: They pull him into the round.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: He that marries a merry lass,
He has most cause to be ●ad;
For let her go free in her merry tricks, she
Will work his patience mad.
But he that marries a scold a scold, etc.
He that weds with a roa●ing girl,
That will both scratch and bite ▪
Though he study all day to make her away,
Will be glad to please her at night.
And he that copes with a sullen wench,
That scarce will speak at all,
Her doggedness more than a scold or a whore,
Will perpetrate his gall.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hey down down, etc.
He that's matched with a turtle dove,
that has no spleen about her,
Shall waste so much life in the love of his wife,
He were better be without her.
But he that marries a scold, a scold, etc.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: O scorn upon scorn, torment upon torment. Let me rather be buried alive then bear this. 〈◊〉 she gets loose. Slaves, rascals, get ye all out of my doors. By virtue of my nails, I charge ye. ●e not leave an eye or a no●e amongst ye

sp.speaker: How. Wid. Bull. Anu.
sp.l: O lord, oh lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come bouncing after my boys.

sp.speaker: Fir.
sp.l: O how am I wronged.

div.stage: Ex. omnes preter Fit. Tri. Bull.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Sure I did apprehend this mirth as ●ight as could be possible the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Trid.
sp.p: Madam, I see too much of your vexation; and indeed I suffer too much with you. As I am a gentleman I will give you right friendly council, if you will hear me.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sir I have perceived humanity in you and do love it in you. But I know not what to do, nor whom to hear. I am fallen into the pit of bondage, and will take any course for my redemption. O master Bulfinch.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: This will make to my purpose.

sp.speaker: Fir.
sp.p: Sir I am wronged beyond expression. This gentleman is an eye witness of my sufferings. Pray come in sir. I will hear your counsel together with this gentleman's advice.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Madame, your case is in my apprehension, most desperate, yet 〈…〉 comfort in regard you seek advice and counsel. Mine is ever ready, and more fortunate oftentimes the judicious. For I do nothing but upon good reason and deliberation.

div.trailer: The end of the third act.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Sir I beseech your worship, deal not so severely with me.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sirrah I will teach you how to deal with dealers, and not with virtuous gentlewomen; bring innocency before justice; and be able to lay nothing to her charge.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Indeed sir, the captain informed me of her; and said he would be here ready to accuse her. Good sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Most officious sir. What warrant had you? None. What is the captain's name? you know not. Where's his lodging? you are ignorant. But here was your cunning; it appears most plainly, that you thinking her to be one of the trade, thought to make a prey of her purse: which since your affrightment, could not make her open unto you, you thought to make her innocency smart for't. I will make your knavery smart for't directly. Come is the mittimus ready? give me't —

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Good your worship, hold your hand. For my poor family's sake.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Here take him forth, and let the next constable convey him to Newgate.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Sir 'tis the first time that ever I offended in this kind. I pray your worship be of a better mind towards me.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Away I say directly. As I am in my right mind and Midlesex. I will show my justice on thee.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Does the knave laugh? Bring him back. May a man ask the cause of your mirth? Vex. Sir I have laughed at the vexation of a thousand in my days. I hope I may have leave once in my life to laugh at mine own.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: O is it so? Pray hold you merry sir.

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, ha —

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now lady, whereas you were brought before me as a delinquent, I retain you as my mistress. I like her beyond measure. A pretty young thing: new brought to a pace! Ah, h●! She has committed a little country folly, as she privately confesses. What's that ● it may stand in rank with that they call virtue here; and than she is content to live as privately as I please. She shall up, I will winter and summer her before she shall see a high way of this town. She's for my turn directly. Mistress Holdup, is your name say you?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
Camitha Holdup sir. A poor gentlewoman. My father
bore the office of a commissioner for the peace in the West country, till misfortune wrought his estate out of his hands.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Holdup! I have heard of him, and know what 'twas that sunk him. He lived by the sea side; 'twas trading with the pirates. Buying their goods, and selling them victuals;

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: 'Tis too true sir. He paid so dear for't at last, that I have no more, but my bare breeding, and what I bear about me to live upon.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Which is enough ● enough directly; if you can bear yourself discreetly, and contain yourself within those bounds of fortune, in which I'll plant you. Alas good soul, weep not; let money and authority be thy comfort. By which thou shalt feel no want, nor fear no danger. But to our business. I have already acquainted you with my niece Constances' disease, and that she is removed out of my house for her health. I will lodge you at a trusty tenant's house where she is unknown. You shall take her name upon you.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Which is mine own already.

sp.speaker: S●u.
sp.p: And if you can but a little counterfeit her melancholy, you may freely pass for her; and my accesses to thee, my sweet girl, shall crown us with fullness of delight and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Sir, you have most worthily made me your own; and all my study shall be to obey you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now had I but ● fit attendant for the person of my love ▪

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Some simple honest body sir.

sp.speaker: Squ
sp.p: Then we were fitted. How now.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: My lady luckless man desire to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Stand you by unseen a while. Send him in. I do expect some message now, in the behalf of her unlucky ladyships wise brother, master widgi●e, touching my niece. Now stend how does my good lady?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I left her very ill sir; for she has beaten me, and thrust me out of doors with her own hands, without penny in my purse, or other cloak o'my back, than the bare livery, that a cast serving man can not shake off, of knave and beggar.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Thou leftest her very ill indeed. But well, thou wouldst have me be a means to reestablish thee in thy lady.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: In her service sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I speak by a figure Humphrey: for to be inward with, or indeed within a mistress, is to be a survey in the most courtly phrase.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Ay sir. Those are convenient servants sir. We are covenant servants. They are respected above husbands: we abased beneath slaves. They purchase place, honours, and offices oftentimes with their ladies 〈…〉, when we find not our wages without hard words, and are in fear, (Poor snakes) to have our sloughs pulled over our ears before the year go about. We drudge for our ladies, they play with their ladies: but the best is, we labour and sweat it out for our ladies, when they are fain to talk physic, and lie in for their ladies.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Most intelligent Humphrey. Let us retire to the purpose. Put ●ase I have a mistress in store for you; to whom I may commend you upon my own credit, and undertake for your entertainment and means by my own purse. What would you say? what would you do?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir, I will say over the gent. usher's grammar to you, and do her service by the rules.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well said directly. Incipe humfride. Say your part.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: In a gentleman usher there be eight parts. Boldness, neatness, flattery and secrecy, rewarded. Diligence, obedience truth and honesty, unrewarded.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: What is his boldness.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: His boldness is the use of his manhood in right of his lady's honour, degree, place or privilege, at home, abroad, in private or public meeting, for the hand, for the w●ll, for the what she will, for the what she calls.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: How is it rewarded?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: By obtaining of suits made out of cast gowns or petticoats. Which if he be a tailor, as most of our middle sort of professors are, he is thereby made a man in spite of the proverb, and thrust into the high way of advancement.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Perge Humphrey his neatness now?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p:
His neatness consists most diuersly ▪ sir. Not only in the decent wearing of those clothes and clean linen, pruning his hair, rustling his boots, or ordering his shoes ties; these are poor expressions, a journey man Barbar will do't. But to
do his office neatly, his garb, his pace, his postures, his co●es on and his comes off, complements, his visits 〈◊〉 ▪

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: His howdees.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: In which a profound judgement could be puzzled.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I believe thee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: And the most absolute or artificial memory set o'the rack. To be able to relate how this lady's tooth does; and tother lady's toe. How this lady's milk does: and how tother's doctor liked her last water: how this lady's husband; and how tother ladies dog slept last night: how this child, that monkey, this nurse, that parrot, and a thousand such. Then his neatness in chamber-work, or about the person of his lady, in case her maid or her woman be otherwise occupied, to convey a pin into her ruff neatly, or add a help to her head dressing, as well as John among the maids, lastly, his dexterity in carving, and his discretion in marshalling of meats; to give every mess the due service, and every dish his lawful pre-eminence.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: And how is this neatness rewarded Humphrey?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Doubly sir: at board and at bed ▪ by good bits, and the love of the chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well Humphrey, because we will not make this scene too long, we will omit the rest: only why are your last four parts, diligence, obedience, truth and honesty unrewarded?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir. They are parts that spring out of virtue, and are therefore born with their reward in their mouths, and ought to expect no further from any service in these times.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Most edifying Humphrey. I have a mistress in store for thee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I long to see her sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Didst thou never see my niece Constance?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: No sir. But I have heard she is diseased with melancholy; and if she should prove mad too, like my old lady, I were then as far to seek as ere I was.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p:
Fear it not humfrey. My 〈◊〉 ease thy care. Niece come forth. [enter Holdup.]I shall fit you with a servant. Fall to your postures Humphrey. Your garb. [he does his postures]so. Your pace. So. Your congee. So. Hand your lady. Good. Arm your lady. Good still. Side your lady. Very good. Draw out your lady. Excellent. Present
your lady. Singular well, good Humphrey.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sir, I can shoulder my lady too: but that is when she takes coach; and foot my lady, when she alights.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Precious Humphrey, I admire thy art.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I learned all of a good old lady's man in the strand sir, that must be nameless.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Now Humphrey, walk your lady to the burse.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Oh most ostlerly spoken! Under correction sir, wait your lady I pray sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well said Humphrey. Here's something for my instruction. Now wait your lady to the burse. She has some trifles to buy there. I will find you there presently, and conduct you to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: What shall I do with all this sir? I would indeed but buy an ounce or two of thread; some netting pins and needles, and a frame to flourish my work on. Hereafter I will work in gold and silver, if you please, for your own wearing.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: As I would wish! her simplicity takes me above her beauty. Go I say. I'll follow. Methinks I e'en feel myself, thank myself for being in this good humour. What I have is mine own, and I will be merry with it directly. —

div.head: Act. iv. Sce. ii.
div.stage: Enter Fitchow, Tridewell, bullfinch, widgeon, anvile.

sp.speaker: Fitc.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you now know the calamity I suffer under. And you have showed me the best way to comfort: for which I thank you. I have given you my resolution for a divorce, upon condition. Before which, I must promise you nothing sir. But I assure you in the mean time, you stand prime in my affection: for I have in all found you a right worthy gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Madam, I have not utterance to declare my acceptance of your love. It must therefore be locked up in my breast, the treasure of my heart. Now for the condition upon which your divorce depends, we must see that performed, and then —

sp.speaker: Fitc.
sp.p: Sir, I will make good more than I now may promise.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You speak nobly.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: It relishes a little ● do much of womanly willfulness I confess. But all my wilfulness (That I'll promise you sir) shall die in the end of this business.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Well then, before your discreet neighbour m. Bulfinch here. If you have not your will in this, I will disclaim in your favour hereafter. Sir, the condition is (As you may remember —

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend it sir. That sir Paul Squelch his niece be first married or contracted, and then she consents to a divorce: and that you be assistant to her brother here to obtain her for him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: To which I promise my ready help, only I must not appear in the business.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I will only appear in it, for I will not be seen in the matter.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: As how sir?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: As thus sir. I will keep your counsel: not only in holding my peace to all the world, but in saying nothing to sir Paul himself. D'ye apprehend me sir?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And thank you sir. Now every man to his part m. widgeon, you have both your sisters and my best directions already, which I doubt not but with the help of your governor you will make good use of. Madam will you in, and but wish well to our proceedings, and trouble your thoughts no further.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, what help he has of me, is for the ladies and his own sake, not yours d'ye hear.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No blustering now good governor: prithee restrain thy fury. Thou canst never hear nor speak to that gent. with any patience; and yet he is on our side now. Prithee let's lose no time. I never longed more for my mother's coming from a christening, than to be at this Northern lass. —

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Wanton, you have begun propitiously: proceed but confidently, and I'll warrant thee a wealthy husband by it, or a composition that may prove the better purchase.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
Sir, be you and this lady but as confident of my fidelity,
and trust me in this action, and if I break not the toils your kinsman is in, and make you mistress of my interest in sir Paul, let all the good you intended me, be a lockram coif, a blue gown, a wheel and a clean whip. You are sure the lady will yield to divorce, if Constance whom I now personate be first married or contracted.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Right. She does but hold off till then, and that wilfully; because she fears it is for Constances' love only, that her husband desires the divorce.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And you are sure that Constance is safe from her discovery.

sp.speaker: Tr●.
sp.p: I upon the hazard of my discretion.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: To any then that knows her not very well, if I appear not the same Constance — you have given me her character right?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: The best that we can possibly.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay, I have a further help then, you both imagine yet.

sp.speaker: Tri. Tra.
sp.p: May we know it.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: It shall be no secret. My servant Howdee, whom you and sir Paul, suppose his lady turned away, was by her ladyship taught only to feign it; and cunningly instructed to work himself into the service of Constance, to further her brother's proceedings. And since fortune has put him upon me, whom he takes to be the same mistress, if I make not apt use of it —

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: 'Tis most fairly ominous. Come lady. He cannot. but be at hand; and our stay may do hurt, (You remember the doctor's lodging I told you of, and sir Phillip's appointment to meet you there an hour hence?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: All sir. I would use no other. She is there already. Ex.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: No more then; away. Fare you well sweet creature.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p:
If my deceit now, should be discovered, before my work be ended, my brain tricks might perhaps, in stead of all these fair hopes, purchase me the lash. fore Venus. my flesh e'en trembles to think on't. It brings likewise into my consideration, the baseness of my condition; how much unpitied the punishment of a whore is, and how suddenly it overtakes her? My joint conspirators are in no danger. I only run the
hazard, though they are as deep in fact as myself . Well. If I scape this pull, and draw any fortune by't, I'll change my function sure. A common whore? I'll be a nun rather. They come most fitly, and I must into my fit — withdraws behind the hanging.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Indeed sir, it was my lady's plot, but you must take no notice of it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'll thank her with all my heart, and she shall never know on't.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: But if sir Paul, my now master should discover my deceit, how shall I scape his vengeance.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: What dost thou think of me, weak fellow? Am not I a commander, ha?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Ay, in the war captain: but he is a justice of peace, and a commander of captains in Midlesex, sends two or three drunken ones to Newgate at a clap sometimes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fear no discovery Humphrey. Let me but see her, and I'll warrant thee.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: She'll see none but sir Philip, you must be nobody else. Remember that: you must know no other name you have. Now if you can sir Philip it handsomely there's it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I warrant thee, and my governor shall sir Philip me at every word; and if I do not sir Philip her, better than ever she was Phillips in her life, then say I am no legitimate widgeon.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: ●is pa●● your strength or reach either by forty I believe. I doubt your middle finger is too short master Widgin●.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Well, I must venture it. Here she comes. Has a baby.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What's she doing. Ods me ● making a baby I think are you good at that i'faith? I'll be at that sport with you, it shall cost me a fall else.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O she has a hundred such ● pish toys. E●ne now she was great with child forsooth as she could go. And was persuaded she had a child as big as I in her belly. I wondered at it, and she told me she had had a hundred there as big in her days.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I but she knew not what she said. By and by, I must be a man-midwife forsooth and deliver her: for 'twas passed all woman's skill? Now she thinks she is brought a-bed , and nurses the child herself.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And who's the father?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O none but sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'll father it as well as he. Is't a boy or a girl trow ▪ would she would make a christning banquet while we are here. Hark she sings.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Peace wayward barn; oh cease thy mo●e:
Thy far more wayward daddy's gone:
And never will recalled be
By cries of either thee, or me:
For should we cry,
Until we die,
We could not scent his cruelty.
Ballow, ballow, etc.
H●e needs might in himself foresee,
What thou successively mightst be;
And could he then, (Though me forego)
His infant leave, ere he did know,
How like the dad
Would be the lad,
In time, to make fond maiden's glad
Ballow, ballew, etc.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How is this pretty Mrs. Constance, that you complain of your love before he be lost?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Who be you I pray?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray thee tell her governor. I ha' not the heart to lie now.

sp.speaker: Anu.
sp.p: It is sir Philip lady, come to do you right. De● hear?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Yes sir, I hear you vary we'll; and could e'en wish i' my heart I could believe you.

sp.speaker: Anu.
sp.p: Speak yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
You may mistress Constance; for as I am an honest man,
I never meant to wrong you.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I do believe you sir. But pray protest no more by that name till you make yourself such by marrying me. You have gotten a barn by me, I is sure o'that.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I come for the same purpose sweetheart. I'll both father and keep thy child, and make thee an honest woman. Give me your hand before this gentleman, and your servant here; and say but the word; I'll get a licence presently, fetch you away, and dispatch you tonight .

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Marry me, marry me, quoth the bonny lass: and when will you begin.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As for thy wedding lass we'll do well enough, in spite ● 'The best of thy kin.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: I can but thank you, obey you, and pray for you sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Governor; wilt thou believe me? It e'en pities my heart, to wrong so sweet a piece of simplicity. But fortune has dressed her for me to seed on; and I'll fall to.

sp.speaker: Anu.
sp.p: Or the devil to choke you. Well boisterous master Tridewell, your ropes end hath driven me into a business, here, deserves a whole rope. But I hope that destiny attends not me, though this marriage be his: and since it is his fate, fair befall it him, I am discharged

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come governor, we are agreed let's go that we may hie us again, and dispatch.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay sir. You shall not say, you married me for naught: you shall hear me sing before you go.

sp.speaker: Anu.
sp.p: What an ouzel 'tis ● she means he shall marry her for a song. By’r lady a competent modern portion.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: As I was gathering Aprill's flowers,
He● straight let fall one of his showers;
Which dra●e me to an arbour.
'Twere better I my lap had filled.
Although the wet my clothes had spilled,
Then to ha' found that harbour
For there a subtle serpent was,
Close lying, lurking in the grass.
And there while harmless thinking I,
still watching when the shower would die,
Lay listening to a bird,
That singing sat upon the bower,
Her notes unto the falling shower,
The snake beneath me stirred;
And with his sting gave me a clap,
That swelled my belly not my lap.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By my troth 'tis pretty.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: And by my conscience 'tis true, 'twere made i' Durham, on a lass of my bigness.

sp.speaker: Anu.
sp.p: And in thy clothes I believe.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: But will you be 'gan now, than all my joy leaves me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sweet soul, thou shalt have thy joy again. I will joy thee, enjoy thee, and over joy thee. Governor let us fly about this business. I will not sleep, before I have got a licence, stolen her away, wedded her, bedded her, and put her in her wits again.

sp.speaker: Anu.
sp.p: Are you able to do that think you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'll warrant thee: for all maids are mad till they be married.

sp.speaker: Anu.
sp.p: What say you to that lady. P●x on you, I run● sweet hazard to advance your fortune, do I not?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Remember your covenant with master Tridewell captain. And when the work is done, here's my hand, you shall partake of what I get by't. And hark you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: She may perhaps, when she comes to herself, and finds me to be no sir Philip, be a little startled. But I mean the first night to put so much of my own love into her, as shall work out his I doubt not, or any his that came there before me.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: O gentlemen! my masters coming, all's spoilt if he take you. Part quickly.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Is mine uncle com'd? and must we part then?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Kiss, and part; kiss and part.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Sweet heart, not a word of me till I come to fetch you off with honour.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: All benisons be with you. Indeed you be the goodliest man, that ere made maiden fain.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Poor heart she dotes. I do not know how much I am in debt to my conscience, till I have made her amends. —

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: This may breed good blood. If I come but as well off of my old uncle, as am like to come on with my young Cose●, here will be a match unlooked for; a match without treaty; a match untalked or unheard of. He is coming before I have shifted my face. Methinks I hear the rusting of his bristles hither. Yet my lips must stand the assault; pray love the porcupine, leave none of his quills in 'em.

div.head: Act. iv. Sce. v.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Where's my girl? My honey sweet girl? Kiss me; kiss I say directly: I'll secure thee. As I am a man of authority, and that of Midlesex, I'll secure thee. Ha my lass, these lips have the true elixir in 'em indeed, to restore youth and strength; passed all Medea's charms, or what the poets would have fai●ed. How now 〈…〉 Love? I hope my niece's habit has not wrought her disease into thee.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: No: now I see you sir, I am well: perfectly well: yet pardon me sir. Your absence cannot but breed me fear, when I have leisure to think on my unworthy condition, and the danger I undergo in't.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: 'Twas a thousand pities that this wench was seduced. She might have made a wife for a good esquire. She would serve a tradesman yet, most unblemishably. And when I have done with her, doing that for her, as I mean to do. She may perhaps match with a younger brother, purchase him a place, advance his fortune, to be able in the end to repay her with a ladyship. 'tis not without a precedent; and I will help her to follow the example directly. For what I have is mine own, and I will be merry with it. Ha my bird, my chick ● kiss me. Kiss me up. So. Kiss me up I say. So again. Thou hast don't directly. Maintain it now, with a cordial kiss. So, so, so ▪ good. Very good; and while it is so, a word with you in private. Come my bird, mh mh mh.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Sit, there's a woman below. —

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sir, what have I to do with any woman below: do you with your woman below, I am very well here.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Is the old man mad trow. Sir, she will have to do with you above, if you speak not with her below. I had much ado to keep her down stairs, her case is so lamentable she says. I never saw a woman so importunate in my life sir. You must down sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I am down already. All's naught. What limb of the devil is 't? Dost thou know her?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: She says she is wife to a constable sir, that you lately committed; and if your wor. dos not release him presently, that he's undone, and she's undone, all their children are undone, that unborn in her belly is undone, and I know not how many more are undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Hell take her. How could she know that I was here?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: She spied you in the street sir, and followed you, and follow you she would, had you gone into the privy chamber she swears; her cause enforces her she says. And she is so great with child too, that no man dares give her a thrust to keep her back. I hear her blow up stairs.

sp.speaker: S●n.
sp.p: Keep her down, I'll follow thee —

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Good sir be pitiful for the woman's sake, and release him. Perhaps her reckoning is out, and she has nobody to call the midwife.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I must home to my clerk then: for I cannot write here; nor do any good besides I am so vexed. But I will return to thee in the evening, duck: and since I am so apt to be spied, ● will come disguised.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Indeed I'll put out the candle when you are here then, for I shall never endure to see other shape of man. O these trunk ho●● are a comely wearing.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I will be disguised directly. I will run through all the shapes of Jupiter, befor● I will again be prevented. Farewell. O my sweet! At seven in the evening expect me. —

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Sweet sayst thou? Thou art not I'll swear. I am glad he was prevented. I should never held out a course with him, that cannot endure a breathing: a cheese-shop on fire cannot outstink him.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Your uncle's gone mistress, and says he will be here at seven o'clock again. But shall I tell you a five thing mistress?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Yea marry Humphrey, what may that be and 'tis not of sir Philip

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: But it is of him mistress. He says he will bring a coach for your at six o'clock to fetch you away: will you go with him?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: By my soul that will I an't be all the world over.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: How shall you uncle find you at 7 then?

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: We'll leave him at six and sevens. I mean betwixt both. 'twill be trim trust me. And hearest thou me Humphrey. Thou must bid mistress Trainwell son to me a little before six ● for a very good reason.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Hmh —

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Nay, it shall hinder nothing. We'll away the faster.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I think she be in her wits already. If not, I must humour her, though I be put to the trouble to shift her away again. She shall mar no sport that's certain.

sp.speaker: Hol.
sp.p: Come with me Humphrey, thou shalt go e'en now, and tell her; and I'll be packing up the while. —

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: This clinches. I shall win my lady's heart for ever. To manage two such businesses more, were enough to raise me agent for a state.

div.trailer: The end of the fourth act.

div.head: Act. v. scene i.
div.stage: Pate in a doctor's habit. Traynwell, Constance.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: To discourse a tedious lecture unto you, lady, in speaking philosophically of the disease of melancholy, were to show more learning than discretion. There are large volumes of it in print, to very slender purpose.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, I desire rather your discretion, than the gloss of learning. I am rather governed by the wholesome effects of the one, than the smooth directions of the other.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: To the point then lady. I see no reason why I should vex and torment this delicate and tender body, with physic. Her disease is melancholy; the cause of this disease I have found apparently in the two hours probation since you left her with me, to be love, which she hath so greedily taken in, that it hath overwhelmed her spirits, and turned the faculties of all her senses into a rude confusion, sending forth the use of them extravagantly.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, I must not only approve, but applaud your skill. 'tis love indeed, and ● am right glad that your opinion jumps with my own knowledge: for now I doubt not of your speedy address to the cure.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: 'Tis done in three words. The party that she loves, must be the doctor, the medicine, and the cure.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, the gentleman is below, he came with me, only I would not bring him to her fight without your approbation, scaring it might do hurt.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Pray call him up, on peril of my judgement. Ex. Tray.give me your hand Mrs. Constance. I have good news for you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: 'Tis a long while ●ine I hear● only.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: The gentleman, whom you love best, shall be your bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: He is wed already sir. Another wife would gar him be put down at gallows: an ● I would not be sh●e for all the worldly good that ere I saw with 〈…〉. And of my conscience I'll be none of his 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: She prattles very prettily methinks . Married already? Sure Cupid shot you with a forked arrow out of his crossbow. But what will you say lady, i● by my Ar● I render this gentleman unmarried again, and a suitor unto you presently?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Marry ▪ shall I tell you what I'll say sir? That deserves hanging worse than tother matter, you would poison his wife by your art, would ye? and make your gown there the hangman's ●ee the second time? It looks as it had been once his already; and you like such a doctor I must tell ye, by your leave. God bless me from thee. Mrs. Trainwell where are you?

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Out of her wits say they? I fear she is wiser than all of us, that have to do with her. She knows my gown better than I do: for I have had but two hours' acquaintance with it. 'tis no longer since I hired it of the hangman's merchant a broker. It might ha' been Lopus' gown for ought I know.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Ii.
div.stage: Enter Traynwell and luckless to them.

sp.speaker: Tray.
sp.p: They are fallen out I think.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
O Mrs. Trainwell, for dear charity's sake ha' me soon
fro' this man: for I'll ne'er take only thing at him. He talks of poisoning.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By my faith you wrong me: nor of any poisoning purpose. I was but putting a case of —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Pray put up your pipes sir. I like not your music: troth nor his countenance nather. Sweet Mrs. Trainwell gar me be shut on him. Now all the joys of immortality light of ye sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Is that the gent?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes sir. Pray observe. But how fell you out sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I must first salute him by your favour. Sir, all the accumulations of honour shower down upon you.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.p: Sir. May you reap the whole harvest of your fruitful wishes.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Dear sir, keepe further fro' him.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: But one word sweet lady; and you shall have the whole benefit of his presence to yourself .

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Be not afraid sweetheart, he dares not hurt sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: In troth he breathes to near him.

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.p: I'll warrant you. What has he done to move her thus? I know not what this obscure doctor is. But m. Tridewell put me upon him; and his approved honesty has and must kill all m●s trust in me.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Your coach is ready at door you say.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ye● my most delicate doctor.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: As you find her then after a few words away with her. I have performed my part sir. I'll hold the discreet governess in talk in the next room.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.p: But one word call ye this?

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: I ha' done sweet soul. Lady I have instructed the gent. Shall we leave them?

sp.speaker: Tr●.
sp.p:
One word, by your leave first m. doctor, and I'll attend you. Sir not alone my discretion, but my reputation lies at stake: and I make no doubt of your nobleness upon your kinsman's word, my complotter in this business. Therefore while I hold argument with the doctor (Who shall by no means perceive our deceit) slip you away with her in your coach, where m. Tridewell ▪ hath appointed, till the evening; and let me alone to scuffle with the old man the while ▪ and than I doubt
not all our troublesome labours shall have a peaceable end. I'll send old madcap to your lady in a thunderclap. But noble sir, your reputation —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My life and honour be her guard, and your security.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: No more sir. I'll lay no conjurations upon so noble a spirit. Come master doctor —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But do you love me Constance?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: O right we'll sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And will you be my woman?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I is sure, I'll never be mine own else.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you will not go away with me now, if I request you?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Any whither but to bed before we be married.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What from your governess, your uncle, and all the world?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: And thank you too sir. And ta'me but fro' this ill looking doctor; for I shall be we'll with you sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, since you trust me so well, we two will not part till we are lawfully made one.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Heaven bliss the hour you speak in, and all saints be witnesses.

div.head: Act. v. Sce. iii.
div.stage: Enter squelch, meeting Trainewell, and pate.

sp.speaker: Squ
sp.p: Where's this doctor? where's this melancholy gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: O me is he come?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Is this her uncle?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Even he sir. Where's my charge; mistress Constance?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: S●ue ye sir I'll go find her —

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Where's my charge? I'll go find her! What's the meaning?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: She was here but now sir, while the music played. And we withdrew our sclues, thinking she might sleep sir.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: There went a coach away as I came in. Whose was it?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: A coach sir? Alas I am afraid; my flesh trembles.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: At what in your great master the devil's name? Where's my niece?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir here came in one master widgeon, the lady Luckless' brother —

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: As acquainted with the doctor sir —

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: And he saw her sir. But seemed to depart, when we withdrew ourselves to talk about the cure.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Very very well. While you were wisely talking about the cure, a widgeon flies away with the patient. Where's this doctor? Doctor I say. Doctor! He's run away too, my life on't. A mere plot, a conspiracy; 'tis so directly, below there. I can not see how it can be otherwise. Ent. clerk.saw you the doctor? Yes sir, he went now forth at the water-gate, and took boat in haste.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Exceeding well ▪ how came your discretion acquainted with this doctor?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir he was reported to me by very good judgements, to be a rare practitioner.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: A most rare fellow, and does admirable tricks, by slight of heels. But I may perhaps outrun 'em —

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: My purge works as I wished. I am amused though at the flight of the doctor. But I have too many businesses to entertain new thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: May I believe it, good sir? may I be so happy, that my brother has her?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: As I have truth in me, I am most credibly told so. Marry the worst is, her uncle is so mad at their escape, that he will never give consent to the match, whereby her portion will be less.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Hang him clod. My will shall be a portion sufficient to my brother, I care not, though he give her not a penny, so Wat has the wench.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p:
Make you no more doubt of that, than I do madam, who have upon the report of it already, prepared the learned of the civil law, those that you nominated of your good acquaintance, and are forward to do you the best office,
who have appointed to meet before the judge of the archdeacon's court presently, whither I have promised to bring, and will attend you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: But the other side must be summoned by process.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sir Philip hath warning already madame; and without needless process will be there before you, and wait your comming. So that myself and his servant, who have never been both absent from one of your companies, since your marriage, justly deposing you never did the realest rite of marriage, the bed office, madame; you both consenting, and desiring a divorce, it is instantly granted, without any proceedings in law. So that all will be ended in three whispers. Ods pity, look who here is.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: O are you here my lady Luckless ?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: 'Twas time you found me sir; you might ha' mistaken my name else. For within this heure, I might have returned the ancient title of your friend, and Awdery Fitchow.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Slow wov, where is my niece?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Where are your wits sir? you come upon me indeed ● what niece? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: My niece Constance, that your brother Widgin stole from the doctor, and is stowne away withal. But he must not think to scape so? I may take him, and his duck too, in my Decoy, before they be coupled, as sure as your ladyship or your Fitchow ship, and they think yourselves.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Sure the old gentleman is fallen mad. What hath happened?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: The plot smells of your ladyship's policy; your ladyships lily white fist is foul in the business. But I will have a about at fisticuffs in law with your ladyship: your great acquaintance, and alliance in the whatshical. Court No●●b●● 〈◊〉 your power there must not carry it, my great lady. Directly it must not.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Your ●re an uncivil greasy companion, to upbraid and revile me thus in my own house.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O good madame, hurt not yourself with anger better laugh it out.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: He makes me forget myself by his example. Sir you are a commissioner for the peace I take it. Does it become a man of your place and gravity, to fly out in these extremes? You spend too much breath in these loud notes, very hurtful to the lungs, if you will fall into a lower key, and speak peaceably, I will answer you.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I pray you, forsooth, or sweet madam, or what you please; where is my niece?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Will you believe me sir? you may: for 'tis truth, as I have any; and before this worthy gentleman; I never saw your niece in my life; only I have heard she is a pretty gentlewoman: likely to make a good match, for which I told my brother of her, and would have treated with you for her, could I have spoken with you as I wished by two or three messages. But whither my brother has got her, or where he, or she is of my own knowledge, I cannot say directly.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: She mocks me to my face all this while. Well goodwife, mistress, madam —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well my lord innkeepers second son: does your provender prick you?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Prick madam: I tell thee thou thing, made up of chippings, broken bear, candle-ends, and sisting of sea coal.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Out you currycomb.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Forbear sweet lady, let him be mad by himself.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I will be so revenged —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: How pray?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: He had been better to have killed a man, ravished ● virgin; nay, done the most dangerous contempt that law could devise to punish, than if I take him to suffer under my revenge.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I'll muster up my constables, and send out a privy search immediately. —

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What think you of your brother's success, now madam?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Much the better, that it vexes him so: scurvy foul unouthed fellow.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Look you now madam. See who here comes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister fall down, and adore me for my great achievement . Humphrey kneel down to her that she may dub thee for thy service. Never did the best nosed dogs, that ever were coached for their goodness, hunt more truly, take more bravely, and carry away more cleanly, than we have done this dainty piece of flesh here. Sister kiss her, and be better acquainted: she is mine own flesh, I'll uphold it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: She is a Holdup herself, if I mistake not her name.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Being your flesh brother, her nearest affinity of blood runs in my veins. Therefore with a sister's love I embrace you, and bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Mine uncle will by right wood I fear me. But I'll ne'er greet for that sir, while I have your love.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I know it is she by her tongue, though I never heard her before. Nor ever fear sweet sister, we shall be all friends shortly.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: I would be glad and 'twere so.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sister come hither. Now hear and admire my wit; as well as my fortune. Humphrey come and take thy share of my sister's wonder.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I hope I performed my duty.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Which we must not see unrewarded sister.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: No: I mean to give him my maid, and a hundred marks with her, besides all she has about her.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I am made for ever. I thank your languishing ladyship.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Well said Howdee: for my ladyship is e'en at the last gasp. I am to be divorced within this half hour. But your proceedings brother? How did she receive you at first?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O at first, she was the prettiliest mad that ere you saw. You yourself can not devise to be so mad, as she was.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
And all for sir Philip, she would love none but sir Philip, speak to none but sir Philip. I told her I was sir Philip,
(Ah God a mercy Humphrey: that was thy invention.) Then the little viper hang upon me, not to be shaked off, till I promised her marriage, and to father a child, which, in her distraction, she conceited she had by me. I promised her any thing; so took her into an inner too me, to make all sure, as well within as without; and I so filliped her —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Enough brother, no more. I understand you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But I must have more, and shall never have enough on't. It passeth your understanding and mine too, the delight of it. [Sing]o what a delight she gave me. And how light I am after 〈◊〉 heigh. My pretty sweet rascal.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Enough I say.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You do not love to hear on't, because you lack it. But you shall hear the miracle it wrought sister. The loss of her maiden head recovered her wits. I made her right and straight in an instant. And now she loves me in my own person; knows me for a widgeon, and will not give her what for the best sir Philip of them all. And longs for nothing but the priest and bed time. Ha my sweeter and sweeter i my governor's gone for a licence.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: So, ha you done now?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'll undertake —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Yet again.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That Humphrey, and I with the tricks and trinkets, we have about us will cure all the mad maids of her standing in the town. And do not think, but much may be gotten to profess it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You have made a large relation master widgeon, and a pleasant, I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O I could live and die in this discourse sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Lady do you think of the time?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I will instantly along with you. Hewdee come you with me. Brother, the search hath passed this house already. You any go in with your sweetheart, and stay here safely. Go in, and keep close, till I send to meet me at supper.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: In and in sister, and be close enough, fear not —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Now sir when you please.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I am your servant lady —

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Mistress, I will go no further in this business, than you have limited me in your directions: 'twill be revenge enough for my disgrace to make him see his error.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Therefore be discreet and secret. The disguise he is in I have told you. The place is this. At the door you shall leave me. The hour 7 o'clock .

sp.speaker: Vex.
sp.p: Mistress, I will not watch more truly at midnight, than I will pray for you for this discovery. I will instantly call my privy-search, guard, and catch a bird, of justice in the lime-twigs of his own warrant. —

div.head: Act. v. scene ix.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: I tit not speak with sir Paul then, it seems, to know the reason why I am subdoodled thus, in I protest and vow a kind of fool's paradise.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Good sir bear your injury with a man's patience. Sir Paul will not be long absent. And till he comes, my mistress entreats you (For your own good) to take his part upon you, in giving entertainment to divers of his friends, who are invited hither to a feast tonight .

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: H● you any whitpots?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Much better meat sir. But here's the strangeness of it; and the only occasion that requires you aid in the entertainment. This great supper or feast (As I may properly call it) was appointed by sir Poule himself, the money to buy the provisioned delivered by his own hand, to his own servant; the guests of his own election; vet he, out of the multiplicity of cross affairs, that have happened this day, hath quite forgotten that there was any such preparation, or any such meeting intended, as appears evidently by his absence. But my mistress has got all the meat privately made ready at the next house, on purpose that he should should see nothing —

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: To try is he would forget it or no?

sp.speaker: B●a.
sp.p: Right sir. I have bidden all the guests: and expect them immediately.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: But what must I say to 'em?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Only salute 'em, bid 'em welcome; tell 'em sir Paul was hastily called forth on his majesty's affairs; entreat their patience till his return, which you know will be every sudden although you know not where he is; and so forth, as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Your master abroad and not within say you?

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: Yes. But good sir stay his coming, I pray you, for his good.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I partly apprehend you at full. Mistress Trainwell appointed me to come too with all possible speed. M. nonsense you are well apprehended.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: Only salute 'em, bid 'em welcome. Tell 'em sir Paul was hastily called forth on his majesty's affairs. Entreat their patience till his return, which you know will be very sudden, although you know not where he is. And so forth as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Love has made you a courtier. M Nonsense

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: No I protest and vow. I do but speak as they say. —

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: What have you said sir?

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: What you said I have an ill verbatim else.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I said but the meaning of what you should say, and put it in your own words.

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: No sir. I will take your own words for this matter.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I am beholden to you.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: I am glad fortune has sent one man of civil government before the roarers come. Here comes some of 'em already. I'll down and look to the rest of the house.

div.stage: Enter luckless, Constance, disguised and masqued.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Save you sir. Are you the worshipful of the house?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: I apprehend you sir. —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How sir? —

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Mistake me not I beseech you, I apprehend you to be some great stranger here: because you know the place better than the master of it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You do not mock me sir?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Sir, this is one of the guests?

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: Only salute 'em. Bid 'em welcome —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: Tell 'em sir Paul was hastily called forth on his majesty's affairs —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is this a parrot or a Popingay?

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: Entreat their patience till his return, which you know.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do you know what you say sir?

sp.speaker: Nonsense
sp.p: Will be very sudden, although you know not where he is —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If I did I would not seek him here sir.
